This class is an introduction to the study of culture and human institutions, how they change, and their role in both literate and nonliterate societies.

Most students found this class to be very disappointing, with some referring to it as “the worst class that I have taken at Penn.” Most students found the readings to be long and pointless, and that the class forced them to buy too many books, of which they only read about half. Others noted that the attendance policy was ridiculous and the lectures were “slow moving especially when the material was not that dense.”

Dr. Hesson was generally seen as the better of the two teachers. Students seemed to feel that he was a bit more comfortable during lectures and didn’t go on as many tangents. Many students felt that he should have taught the entire class. Most students noted that Dr. Hesson was “good.”

Many students commented that because they did not learn the information given the poor lecturing of the Professors, they received grades they didn’t deserve. One student said that the grading was “unnecessarily severe.” Many commented that the assignments were unclear and the group presentations were a waste of time. Another student noted that “recitations were very useful maybe 50% of the time.”
